bubbleSortExplanation.name: Bubble Sort
bubbleSortExplanation.description: A simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly compares and swaps adjacent elements until the array is sorted.
steps: Start with the last position in the array as the current end position.
From the beginning of the array, compare each element with the one immediately after it.
If the current element is larger than the next one, swap their positions.
Continue comparing and swapping until you reach the current end position.
The largest value is now at its correct position at the end of the array.
Move the end position one step closer to the start of the array.
Repeat the process until the array is completely sorted.

notes.heading: Bubble Sort Explaination
notes.subHeading: Bubble Sort is one of the simplest sorting algorithms to understand and implement. It works by repeatedly stepping through the list, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they are in the wrong order. The pass through the list is repeated until the list is sorted.

working.step: Compare Adjacent Elements: Start with the first two elements of the array
Swap if Necessary: If the first element is greater than the second, swap them
Move Forward: Continue this process for each pair of adjacent elements
Complete Pass: After one complete pass, the largest element "bubbles up" to the end
Repeat: Repeat the process for the remaining unsorted portion
Optimization: Stop early if no swaps occur in a pass (array is sorted)

applications: Educational Purpose: Perfect for learning sorting concepts
Small Datasets: Acceptable for arrays with less than 50 elements
Nearly Sorted Data: Performs well when data is almost sorted
Memory Constraints: When memory usage must be minimal
Stable Sorting: Maintains relative order of equal elements
advantages: Can detect if list is already sorted
disadvantages: More writes compared to selection sort

heapSortExplanation.name: Heap Sort
heapSortExplanation.description: Heap Sort builds a max heap from the input, then repeatedly extracts the maximum element and rebuilds the heap until the array is sorted.
steps: Build a max heap from the array:
Start from the last non-leaf node and move backward to the root.
For each node, apply Heapify to ensure the max heap property is satisfied.
Once the max heap is built, repeatedly do the following:
Swap the root (largest element) with the last element in the heap.
Reduce the heap size by one (exclude the last sorted element).
Apply Heapify on the new root to restore the max heap property.
Continue until all elements are sorted.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Heap Sort is an efficient comparison-based sorting algorithm that uses a binary heap data structure.

working.step: Build Max Heap: Arrange the array into a max heap.
Extract Max: Swap the root with the last element, reduce heap size, and heapify.
Repeat: Continue until the heap is empty.

applications: Large Datasets: Efficient for large arrays.
Priority Queues: Used in implementing priority queues.
External Sorting: Useful when memory is limited.
advantages: Time complexity is always O(n log n)
disadvantages: Slower than quicksort in practice for small arrays

quickSortExplanation.name: Quick Sort
quickSortExplanation.description: Quick Sort is a divide-and-conquer algorithm that selects a pivot and partitions the array into elements less than and greater than the pivot.
steps: Choose a pivot element from the array (last or first element).
Partition the array into two sub-arrays:
Elements less than the pivot.
Elements greater than or equal to the pivot.
Recursively apply Quick Sort to both sub-arrays.
Combine the sorted sub-arrays and the pivot to form the sorted array.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Quick Sort is a highly efficient divide-and-conquer sorting algorithm. It works by selecting a 'pivot' element from the array and partitioning the other elements into two sub-arrays according to whether they are less than or greater than the pivot. The sub-arrays are then sorted recursively.

working.step: Choose Pivot: Select an element as pivot (first, last, random, or median)
Partition: Rearrange array so elements smaller than pivot come before it
Recursive Sort: Apply quicksort to sub-array of elements less than pivot
Recursive Sort: Apply quicksort to sub-array of elements greater than pivot
Combine: No explicit combine step needed due to in-place sorting

applications: General Purpose: Most commonly used sorting algorithm
Large Datasets: Excellent performance on large arrays
System Libraries: Used in many programming language libraries
Database Systems: Internal sorting in database management systems
Cache Efficiency: Good cache performance due to locality of reference
advantages: Very fast on average for large datasets
disadvantages: Recursive (can cause stack overflow on large arrays)
Performance degrades with poor pivot selection

insertionSortExplanation.name: Insertion Sort
insertionSortExplanation.description: Insertion Sort builds a sorted array one element at a time by repeatedly taking the next element and inserting it into the correct position in the already sorted part of the array.
steps: Start with the first element as the sorted part.
Take the next element from the unsorted part.
Compare it with elements in the sorted part from right to left.
Shift larger elements to the right to make space for the new element.
Insert the new element into its correct position.
Repeat until all elements are sorted.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Insertion Sort builds the final sorted array one item at a time. It is much less efficient on large lists than more advanced algorithms such as quicksort, heapsort, or merge sort. However, it provides several advantages for small datasets and has some performance advantages over other O(nÂ²) algorithms.

working.step: Start from Second Element: Assume first element is already sorted
Pick Current Element: Take the next element from unsorted portion
Find Correct Position: Compare with sorted elements from right to left
Shift Elements: Move larger elements one position to the right
Insert Element: Place current element in its correct position
Repeat: Continue until all elements are processed

applications: Small Arrays: Very efficient for small datasets (< 50 elements)
Nearly Sorted Arrays: Excellent performance on partially sorted data
Online Algorithm: Can sort data as it arrives
Hybrid Algorithms: Used as subroutine in advanced algorithms like Timsort
Linked Lists: Works well with linked list data structures
advantages: Efficient for small or nearly sorted datasets
Online algorithm (can sort as data arrives)
disadvantages: Not suitable for large unsorted arrays

mergeSortExplanation.name: Merge Sort
mergeSortExplanation.description: Merge Sort is a divide-and-conquer algorithm that splits the array into halves, sorts each half, and then merges them back together.
steps: If the array has one or zero elements, it is already sorted.
Split the array into two halves.
Recursively apply Merge Sort to both halves.
Merge the two sorted halves back together:
Compare the smallest elements of both halves and append the smaller one to the result.
Continue until all elements from both halves are merged.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Merge Sort is a stable, comparison-based, divide-and-conquer sorting algorithm that is efficient for large datasets.

working.step: Divide: Recursively split the array into halves until single elements remain.
Conquer: Merge sorted halves by comparing elements.
Combine: Continue merging until the whole array is sorted.

applications: Large Datasets: Efficient for sorting large arrays.
Linked Lists: Well-suited for linked list sorting.
External Sorting: Used when data cannot fit into memory.
advantages: Consistent O(n log n) time complexity
Works well with large data sets
disadvantages: Slower than in-place algorithms for small arrays

selectionSortExplanation.name: Selection Sort
selectionSortExplanation.description: Selection Sort divides the array into a sorted and an unsorted part, repeatedly selecting the smallest (or largest) element from the unsorted part and moving it to the end of the sorted part.
steps: Start with an empty sorted part and the entire array as unsorted.
Find the smallest element in the unsorted part.
Swap it with the first element of the unsorted part.
Move the boundary between sorted and unsorted parts one step forward.
Repeat until all elements are sorted.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Selection Sort is a simple, in-place comparison sorting algorithm. It is noted for its simplicity and has performance advantages over more complicated algorithms in certain situations.

working.step: Find Minimum: Find the minimum element in the unsorted part.
Swap: Swap it with the first unsorted element.
Repeat: Move the boundary and repeat until sorted.

applications: Small Arrays: Useful for small datasets.
Memory Constraints: When memory writes are costly.
Educational Purpose: Good for teaching sorting concepts.

linearSearchExplanation.name: Linear Search
linearSearchExplanation.description: Linear Search checks each element in the array sequentially until it finds the target value or reaches the end of the array.
steps: Start from the first element of the array.
Compare the current element with the target value.
If they match, return the index of the current element.
If not, move to the next element.
Repeat until you find the target or reach the end of the array.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Linear Search is the simplest searching algorithm that checks every element in the list sequentially until the target value is found or the list ends.

working.step: Start from First Element: Begin at the first element in the list
Check Value: Compare current element with target value
Match Found: Return index if element matches target
Move to Next: Continue to next element if no match
End: Return -1 if target not found after checking all elements

applications: Unsorted Data: Works on unsorted datasets
Small Datasets: Good for lists with small number of elements
When Simplicity is Key: Useful when minimal coding is required
disadvantages: Not suitable for sorted or large lists
Can be slow if target is at the end or not present

binarySearchExplanation.name: Binary Search
binarySearchExplanation.description: Binary Search is an efficient algorithm for finding a target value in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half.
steps: Start with the entire array as the search interval.
Find the middle element of the current interval.
If the middle element is equal to the target, return its index.
If the target is less than the middle element, narrow the search to the left half.
If the target is greater than the middle element, narrow the search to the right half.
Repeat until you find the target or the interval is empty.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Binary Search is an efficient algorithm for finding a target value within a sorted array. It works by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half.

working.step: Start with Whole Array: Set low to first index and high to last index
Find Middle: Calculate middle index of current range
Check Middle Value: If target equals middle value, return index
Adjust Range: If target less than middle value, search left half; otherwise search right half
Repeat: Continue until target found or range becomes empty

applications: Sorted Data: Efficient for large sorted datasets
Search Operations: Common in databases and libraries
Indexing: Used in search engines and dictionary lookups
advantages: Very efficient for large sorted datasets (O(log n) time)
disadvantages: More complex than linear search for small arrays

hashSearchExplanation.name: Hash Search
hashSearchExplanation.description: Hash Search uses a hash table to store key-value pairs, allowing for efficient retrieval of values based on their keys.
steps: Create a hash table with a fixed size.
For each key-value pair, compute the hash of the key to determine its index in the table.
Store the value at the computed index.
To search for a value, compute the hash of the key and retrieve the value from the corresponding index.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Hash Search leverages hash tables for fast data retrieval using key-value pairs.

working.step: Hash Function: Compute hash code for the key.
Indexing: Use hash code to determine storage index.
Collision Handling: Resolve collisions using chaining or open addressing.
Retrieve: Use hash function to quickly access value by key.

applications: Database Indexing: Used in hash-based indexes.
Symbol Tables: Compilers and interpreters.
Caching: Fast lookup in caches.

bfsExplanation.name: Breadth-First Search (BFS)
bfsExplanation.description: BFS explores all the vertices of a graph layer by layer, starting from a given source vertex.
steps: Initialize a queue and enqueue the source vertex.
Mark the source vertex as visited.
While the queue is not empty:
Dequeue a vertex from the front of the queue.
For each unvisited neighbor of the dequeued vertex:
Mark it as visited and enqueue it.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Breadth-First Search (BFS) is a fundamental graph traversal algorithm that explores vertices in layers.

working.step: Enqueue Source: Start with the source node in the queue.
Visit Neighbors: Visit all neighbors of the current node.
Repeat: Continue until all reachable nodes are visited.

applications: Shortest Path: Finding shortest path in unweighted graphs.
Web Crawlers: Used in web crawling algorithms.
Social Networks: Finding people within a given distance.
advantages: Finds shortest path in unweighted graphs
Can be used for level-order traversal
disadvantages: Not suitable for very large graphs

dfsExplanation.name: Depth-First Search (DFS)
dfsExplanation.description: DFS explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking, using a stack or recursion.
steps: Initialize a stack and push the source vertex onto it.
Mark the source vertex as visited.
While the stack is not empty:
Pop a vertex from the top of the stack.
For each unvisited neighbor of the popped vertex:
Mark it as visited and push it onto the stack.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Depth First Search (DFS) is an algorithm for traversing or searching tree or graph data structures. It starts at the root node and explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.

working.step: Start at Source: Begin at selected node
Visit Node: Mark node as visited
Explore Neighbors: Recursively visit unvisited neighbors
Backtrack: Return to previous node when no unvisited neighbors remain
Repeat: Continue until all reachable nodes are visited

applications: Path Finding: Used to find paths in a graph
Cycle Detection: Detects cycles in graphs
Topological Sorting: In directed acyclic graphs
Solving Puzzles: Like mazes or Sudoku
Component Identification: Finds connected components in graphs
advantages: Can find path to target quickly if in deep branch
disadvantages: Can get stuck in infinite loops without visited tracking
Stack overflow risk with deep recursion
Not optimal for finding nodes close to root
Can be slower than BFS for shallow solutions

dijkstraExplanation.name: Dijkstra's Algorithm
dijkstraExplanation.description: Dijkstra's algorithm finds the shortest path from a source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted graph with non-negative weights.
steps: Initialize a priority queue and add the source vertex with a distance of 0.
Set the distance of all other vertices to infinity.
While the priority queue is not empty:
Dequeue the vertex with the smallest distance.
For each unvisited neighbor of the dequeued vertex:
Calculate the new distance through the current vertex.
If this new distance is smaller, update it and enqueue the neighbor.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Dijkstra's Algorithm is a classic algorithm for finding the shortest paths from a source node to all other nodes in a weighted graph.

working.step: Initialize Distances: Set all distances to infinity except the source.
Priority Queue: Use a min-priority queue to select the next closest node.
Relax Edges: Update distances for each neighbor if a shorter path is found.

applications: Network Routing: Used in routing protocols.
Map Services: Shortest path in maps and GPS.
Resource Allocation: Project scheduling and resource management.
advantages: Finds shortest path in weighted graphs with non-negative weights
disadvantages: Does not work with negative weights
Can be slow for very large graphs

primsExplanation.name: Prim's Algorithm
primsExplanation.description: Prim's algorithm finds a minimum spanning tree for a connected, weighted graph.
steps: Initialize a priority queue and add the starting vertex with a distance of 0.
Set the distance of all other vertices to infinity.
While the priority queue is not empty:
Dequeue the vertex with the smallest distance.
For each unvisited neighbor of the dequeued vertex:
If the edge weight is smaller than the current distance, update it and enqueue the neighbor.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Prim's Algorithm is a greedy algorithm that finds a minimum spanning tree for a weighted undirected graph.

working.step: Start at Any Node: Begin with any vertex as the starting point.
Grow Tree: Add the smallest edge connecting the tree to a new vertex.
Repeat: Continue until all vertices are included.

applications: Network Design: Designing least-cost networks.
Clustering: Used in clustering algorithms.
Approximation Algorithms: For NP-hard problems.

kruskalsExplanation.name: Kruskal's Algorithm
kruskalsExplanation.description: Kruskal's algorithm finds a minimum spanning tree for a connected, weighted graph by sorting edges and adding them one by one.
steps: Sort all edges in non-decreasing order of their weights.
Initialize a disjoint-set data structure to keep track of connected components.
For each edge in the sorted list:
If the edge connects two different components, add it to the minimum spanning tree and union the components.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Kruskal's Algorithm is a greedy algorithm for finding a minimum spanning tree in a weighted undirected graph.

working.step: Sort Edges: Sort all edges by weight.
Union-Find: Use disjoint-set to detect cycles.
Add Edges: Add edges that do not form a cycle.

applications: Network Design: Designing least-cost networks.
Clustering: Used in clustering algorithms.
Approximation Algorithms: For NP-hard problems.

treeTraversalExplanation.name: Tree Traversal
treeTraversalExplanation.description: Tree traversal algorithms visit all nodes in a tree in a specific order.
steps: Pre-order Traversal: Visit the root, then recursively visit the left subtree, followed by the right subtree.
In-order Traversal: Recursively visit the left subtree, visit the root, then recursively visit the right subtree.
Post-order Traversal: Recursively visit the left subtree, then the right subtree, and finally visit the root.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Tree traversal algorithms systematically visit all nodes in a tree data structure.

working.step: Post-order: Left -> Right -> Root

applications: Expression Trees: Evaluating and printing expressions.
File Systems: Traversing directory structures.
Binary Search Trees: In-order traversal for sorted order.
disadvantages: Can use stack space proportional to tree height

bstExplanation.name: Binary Search Tree (BST)
bstExplanation.description: A BST is a binary tree where each node has at most two children, and for each node, all values in the left subtree are less than the node's value, and all values in the right subtree are greater.

insertion: If the value is less than the current node's value, go to the left child; if greater, go to the right child.
Repeat until you find an empty spot and insert the new value there.
search: If the value matches the current node's value, return it.
If the value is less, search in the left subtree; if greater, search in the right subtree.
If no node is found, the value is not in the tree.
deletion: If the node has no children, remove it directly.
If the node has one child, replace it with that child.
If the node has two children, find the in-order successor or predecessor.
Replace the node's value with the successor/predecessor's value, then delete that successor/predecessor node.

notes.heading: Overview
notes.subHeading: Binary Search Tree (BST) is a hierarchical data structure that maintains sorted data and allows for efficient insertion, deletion, and search operations.
working: Binary Property: Left subtree contains values less than node, right subtree contains values greater
Recursive Structure: Each subtree is also a valid BST
Search Path: At each node, decide to go left or right based on comparison
Dynamic Structure: Tree shape depends on insertion order
Balancing: Unbalanced trees can degrade to linked list performance
applications: Database Indexing: B-trees and B+ trees are variants used in databases
File Systems: Directory structures and file organization
Expression Parsing: Abstract syntax trees in compilers
Priority Queues: When combined with heap properties
Autocomplete: Prefix trees (tries) for text suggestions
advantages: Efficient search, insertion, and deletion (O(log n) average)
Dynamic size - grows and shrinks as needed
disadvantages: Not cache-friendly due to pointer chasing
